            ### Question    
            Which of the following is the source of energy for a cardiac muscle at normal conditions?

            ### Options
            opa. Fatty acids
opb. Ketone bodies
opc. Glucose
opd. Any of the above

### Reasoning Chains for Validation:
- CHAIN: "Cardiac muscle primarily uses fatty acids" -> "Fatty acids are abundant in the bloodstream" -> "Fatty acids undergo beta-oxidation" -> "Beta-oxidation produces ATP" -> 85%
- CHAIN: "Cardiac muscle can utilize ketone bodies" -> "Ketone bodies are produced during fasting or low carbohydrate intake" -> "Ketone bodies can be converted to acetyl-CoA" -> "Acetyl-CoA enters the Krebs cycle" -> "Krebs cycle produces ATP" -> 75%
- CHAIN: "Cardiac muscle can also use glucose" -> "Glucose is metabolized through glycolysis" -> "Glycolysis produces pyruvate" -> "Pyruvate enters the mitochondria" -> "Pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA" -> "Acetyl-CoA enters the Krebs cycle" -> "Krebs cycle produces ATP" -> 80%
- CHAIN: "Cardiac muscle can utilize any of the above sources" -> "Fatty acids, ketone bodies, and glucose are all metabolized" -> "All three pathways produce ATP" -> "Cardiac muscle is adaptable to different energy sources" -> 90%
